overall_score_comment: It's like a relationship contract written by someone who just discovered promises exist.
the_roast:
Rick starts with 'We're no strangers to love' and then immediately treats us like we've never heard of commitment before, explaining it like a PowerPoint presentation at Corporate Romance 101. 'You know the rules and so do I' — buddy, if love had rules this clear, divorce lawyers would be out of business. He's really out here claiming 'you wouldn't get this from any other guy' as if baseline human decency is some kind of limited-time exclusive offer.

The chorus is essentially a checklist of things he promises NOT to do, which is like proposing by saying 'I promise not to set your car on fire or join a circus.' 'Never gonna run around and desert you' is such a specific promise that I'm concerned about Rick's past relationship history. Did someone hurt you in the desert, Rick? The repetition of this chorus roughly fourteen thousand times suggests he's either REALLY committed or trying to convince himself.

Then we get the ultimate passive-aggressive moment: 'Your heart's been aching, but you're too shy to say it' followed by 'Don't tell me you're too blind to see.' So which is it, Rick? Is she shy or blind? Make up your mind! He's diagnosing her emotional state like a motivational poster come to life, claiming 'we both know what's been going on' — if you BOTH know, why are we having this conversation? 'We know the game, and we're gonna play it' makes this whole romance sound like a strategic board game night rather than actual love.

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is a sophisticated metaphor about Rick's career in the furniture moving business — 'never gonna let you down' is about proper lifting technique, while 'run around and desert you' refers to his pledge to never abandon a client mid-relocation to Las Vegas. The repetition represents the monotonous nature of explaining warranty terms to customers.
final_verdict: It's a perfectly adequate promise wrapped in the musical equivalent of bubble wrap — protective, repetitive, and you can't stop popping it even though you know you should. The song that launched a billion internet pranks is basically just Rick Astley reading his relationship terms and conditions out loud for three minutes.
title: Never Gonna Give You Up
